comment_text.mn17:2.1: This sutta acts as a counterbalance to the many places where the Buddha encourages living secluded in the forest. The purpose of the life of solitude is to develop meditation and find freedom. But life is complicated and people are complicated, and sometimes what we think will support us becomes a hindrance. So regardless of how secluded and inspiring a place may be, it is crucial to always reflect on one’s actual progress in developing the wholesome.
comment_text.mn17:3.1: Here I translate upanissaya as “close by”.
comment_text.mn17:3.2: This gives a brief summary of the path of meditation. First one “establishes mindfulness”, i.e. undertakes meditation based on the four satipaṭṭhānas. This leads to samādhi as the mind becomes immersed in the four jhānas. Then, seeing reality with the unclouded clarity of a purified mind, defilements are abandoned and one is freed from transmigration.
comment_text.mn17:4.9: In this case they should leave after reflection, not necessarily “that very day”, since at least they can live comfortably and healthily, which is no small thing.
comment_text.mn17:5.9: Even if life is hard, meditation progress is more important.
comment_text.mn17:7-10.1: In the remaining cases I translate upanissaya as “supported by”.
comment_text.mn17:23.7: The mendicant’s supporters have not fulfilled their duty to provide adequate requisites, so the mendicant is not obliged to take leave from them.
comment_text.mn17:26.7: The idiom “even if driven away” (api panujjamānena) occurs a few times in this sense (MN 122:19.2, AN 7.37:1.1, AN 9.6:6.4).

translation_text.mn17:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn17:1.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
translation_text.mn17:2.1: “Mendicants, I will teach you an exposition about jungle thickets.
translation_text.mn17:2.2: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
translation_text.mn17:3.1: “Mendicants, take the case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.
translation_text.mn17:3.2: As they do so, their mindfulness does not become established, their mind does not become immersed in samādhi, their defilements do not come to an end, and they do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn17:3.3: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.
translation_text.mn17:3.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established, my mind does not become immersed in samādhi, my defilements do not come to an end, and I do not arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn17:3.6: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by.’
translation_text.mn17:3.7: That mendicant should leave that jungle thicket that very time of night or day; they should not stay there.
translation_text.mn17:4.1: Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.
translation_text.mn17:4.2: Their mindfulness does not become established …
translation_text.mn17:4.3: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.
translation_text.mn17:4.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established …
translation_text.mn17:4.6: But the necessities of life are easy to come by.
translation_text.mn17:4.7: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.mn17:4.8: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness does not become established …’
translation_text.mn17:4.9: That mendicant should, after appraisal, leave that jungle thicket; they should not stay there.
translation_text.mn17:5.1: Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.
translation_text.mn17:5.2: As they do so, their mindfulness becomes established, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi, their defilements come to an end, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn17:5.3: But the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are hard to come by. That mendicant should reflect:
translation_text.mn17:5.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …
translation_text.mn17:5.6: But the necessities of life are hard to come by.
translation_text.mn17:5.7: But I didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness for the sake of a robe, almsfood, lodgings, or medicines and supplies for the sick.
translation_text.mn17:5.8: Moreover, while living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …’
translation_text.mn17:5.9: That mendicant should, after appraisal, stay in that jungle thicket; they should not leave.
translation_text.mn17:6.1: Take another case of a mendicant who lives close by a jungle thicket.
translation_text.mn17:6.3: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.
translation_text.mn17:6.5: ‘While living close by this jungle thicket, my mindfulness becomes established …
translation_text.mn17:6.6: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’
translation_text.mn17:6.7: That mendicant should stay in that jungle thicket for the rest of their life; they should not leave.

translation_text.mn17:26.2: As they do so, their mindfulness becomes established, their mind becomes immersed in samādhi, their defilements come to an end, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
translation_text.mn17:26.3: And the necessities of life that a renunciate requires—robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick—are easy to come by.
translation_text.mn17:26.5: ‘While living supported by this individual, my mindfulness becomes established …
translation_text.mn17:26.6: And the necessities of life are easy to come by.’
translation_text.mn17:26.7: That mendicant should follow that individual for the rest of their life; they should not leave them, even if driven away.”
translation_text.mn17:26.8: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn17:26.9: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
